(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed loan 
and  grant,  and  (ii)  proposed  administration  of  a  loan  and  a  grant  to  be  provided  by  the 
Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries Fund for International Development (OFID), both 
to Nepal for the Kathmandu Valley Wastewater Management Project.1   
 
2.  The project will complement past and ongoing efforts of the government toward improving 
wastewater  services  in  the  Kathmandu  Valley.2  The  project  will  invest  in  rehabilitation  and 
expansion  of  the  sewerage  network,  modernization  and  expansion  of  wastewater  treatment 
plants (WWTPs), and improved wastewater management in the Kathmandu Valley. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.    Current status. The population of the Kathmandu Valley was 2.51 million in 2011, and is 
growing at a high rate of 4.3% per annum, while Nepal’s total population is growing at 1.4% per 
annum.3  Rapid  and  unplanned  urban  growth  and  inadequate  investments  in  wastewater 
management have resulted in poor quality wastewater services in the Kathmandu Valley. The 
disposal of untreated sewage  in rivers affects the quality of surface and ground water and 
increases disease incidence, health risks, and associated economic burdens,4 particularly for the 
poor and socially excluded groups, notably women. The focus on wastewater complements and 
builds on past and ongoing Asian Development Bank (ADB) projects in water supply. Since 2000, 
ADB  has  been  working  with  the  government  in  urban  water  in  the  Kathmandu  Valley  in 
developing water sources and treatment plants, improving transmission and distribution networks, 
and undertaking institutional reforms.5 The 27.5-kilometer Melamchi tunnel is a key component of 
the water supply system. It will significantly increase water volumes through transfer of water from 
the Melamchi River to the Kathmandu Valley, and its performance impacts the pace and progress 
of downstream urban projects in the Kathmandu Valley. Further, as part  of the institutional 
reforms, three water and wastewater organizations were created in 2008―the Kathmandu Valley 
Water  Supply  Management  Board  (KVWSMB),  the  asset  owner;  Kathmandu  Upatyaka 
Khanepani Limited (KUKL), the asset operator and service provider; and the Water Supply Tariff 
Fixation Commission (WSTFC), the regulator. These organizations are still in the process of fully 
operationalizing their mandates in an effective and efficient manner.  
 
                                                
1   The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2   Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2011. Technical Assistance to Nepal for Preparing the Kathmandu Valley Urban 
Environment Improvement Project. Manila (TA 7936-NEP). 
3   Sector Assessment (Summary): Water Supply and Other Municipal Infrastructure and Services (accessible from the 
list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
4   The World Health Organization has estimated that environmental factors account for 24% of the total burden of 
disease in Nepal. World Health Organization. 2009. Country Profiles of Environmental Burden of Disease. Geneva. 
The  World  Bank  has  estimated  annual  health  costs  from  environmental  factors  in  Nepal  to  be  
$258 million, or 3.5% of gross domestic product in 2005. World Bank. 2007. Nepal Country Environmental Analysis. 
Washington, DC. 
5   ADB. 2000. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the Kingdom 
of Nepal for the Melamchi Water Supply Project. Manila (Loan 1820-NEP, approved on 21 December 2000, 
effective on 28 November 2001); ADB. 2003. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of 
Directors: Proposed Loans to the Kingdom of Nepal for the Kathmandu Valley Water Services Sector Development 
Program. Manila (Loans 2058-NEP[SF] and 2059-NEP[SF], approved on 18 December 2003, effective on 7 
December 2004); ADB. 2011. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed 
Loan to Nepal for the Kathmandu Valley Water Supply Improvement Project (Loan 2776-NEP[SF], approved on 16 
September 2011, effective on 7 February 2012). The closing date of Loan 1820-NEP was 31 March 2007, and was 
extended to 31 December 2013. Loan 2058-NEP(SF) was closed on 31 December 2008. The closing date of Loan 
2059-NEP[SF] was 30 June 2011 and was extended to 31 December 2014.

2 
4.  Focus on capacity building and service delivery. The project will strengthen KUKL, 
KVWSMB, and WSTFC to increase operational efficiency and improve service delivery, and will 
result in positive impacts on health and quality of life for Kathmandu Valley residents. With the 
completion of the ongoing projects (footnote 5), the Kathmandu Valley will receive an additional 
170 million liters per day (MLD) of water in 2016 (the current average availability of water is only 
100 MLD6). The sewerage system, which is inadequate even to manage existing low levels of 
water supply, will be further overburdened by more than 125 MLD of additional wastewater.7 Of 
five existing WWTPs, only one, which has a capacity of 16.4 MLD, is based on a mechanized 
treatment  process;  the  rest  are  waste  stabilization  pond  systems.  All  of  the  WWTPs  are 
nonfunctional or only partially functional, and require investments for upgrade and renovation. 
The project aims to use energy efficient and mechanized processes to treat approximately 45% of 
wastewater generated in the Kathmandu Valley in 2018 (treatment capacity of 90.5 MLD against 
200.0 MLD wastewater generated) in accordance with the long-term capital investment and asset 
management program, approved by the government for prioritized year-wise investments in water 
supply and wastewater infrastructure in the Kathmandu Valley.8 The project will help to reduce 
pollution  of  the  Bagmati  River9  in  accordance  with  the  Bagmati  Action  Plan,10  and  will 
complement efforts at further improving river basin management under the proposed Bagmati 
River Basin Improvement Project.11  
 
5.  Development partnerships. The efforts of the government and various development 
partners to improve urban services in the Kathmandu Valley have started to achieve the desired 
results.12  Progress  on  the  Melamchi  tunnel  has  been  improving  despite  frequent  political 
disturbances, institutional weaknesses, and poorly performing contractors, and the tunnel is likely 
to be completed in 2016. The ongoing Melamchi Water Supply Project (footnote 5) was adversely 
affected from 2000 to 2006 when several development partners withdrew because of the volatile 
sociopolitical situation and internal conflict in the country at the time. Investments in the project 
are necessary and timely to fully leverage the benefits of ongoing projects. 
 
6.  Lessons. The project was developed using lessons from previous ADB interventions and 
the country assistance program evaluation, which pointed to the need for strategic, well-defined, 
and prioritized urban infrastructure investments.13  The implementation arrangements have been 
kept simple with a focus on using the institutional arrangements created under previous projects 
to ensure continued capacity building and sustainability. An important lesson from earlier projects 
is that stronger emphasis should be placed on the maintenance and rehabilitation of existing 
infrastructure in parallel with the creation of new assets. Accordingly, the project will focus on 
improving  the  existing  sewerage  network  and WWTPs.  Another  lesson  is  that  stakeholders 
should  be  involved  from  the  early  stage  of  project  development;  the  project  has  provided 
adequate resources for participation of various stakeholders. Further, civil works packages have 
been kept sufficiently large to attract qualified international bidders. 
                                                
6   Though the current average availability of water through KUKL is estimated at 100 MLD, availability varies widely 
and ranges from 70 MLD in the dry season to 140 MLD in the wet season.  
7   There is no accurate assessment of the volume of wastewater generated. Estimating from water supply data from 
both KUKL and private sources, average current wastewater generation is assessed as 75 MLD, and an additional 
125 MLD of wastewater is expected with the completion of the Melamchi tunnel.  
8   The Capital Investment and Asset Management Program 2010–2025 was prepared with ADB assistance in 2010. 
9   The Bagmati River is considered a holy river by Hindus and Buddhists. Several Hindu temples are located on its 
banks. 
10  The Bagmati Action Plan (2009–2014) was adopted by the government in August 2009 and is being implemented 
by the High Powered Committee for Integrated Development of the Bagmati Civilization (HPCIDBC). Zone 4 of this 
plan focuses on the urban area of the Kathmandu Valley and the components proposed in the project are 
consistent with the plan. 
11  The project is being prepared through PPTA 8050-NEP: Preparing the Bagmati River Basin Improvement Project. 
12  Development Coordination (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
13  ADB. 2009. Country Assistance Program Evaluation: Nepal. Manila.

3 
 
7.  Context in country programming. The project is consistent with ADB’s Nepal country 
partnership strategy,14 which aims to support Nepal’s peace and development aspirations by 
promoting the following four pillars: (i) broad-based and inclusive economic growth, (ii) inclusive 
social development, (iii) governance and capacity building, and (iv) climate change adaptation 
and environmental sustainability. The project fits into the priority water supply and other municipal 
infrastructure and services sector, identified in the country partnership strategy, and will support 
the country’s peace and development through improved access to basic services. The project is 
included in the Nepal country operations business plan.15   
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact will be sustainable wastewater management for the Kathmandu Valley. The 
outcome will be improved access to, and efficiency of, wastewater services for the residents of 
the  Kathmandu  Valley.  The  project  will  further  consolidate  the  continuing  efforts  of  the 
government and ADB in institutional development and improved governance of wastewater.  
 
C.  Outputs 
9.  The  project  will  broadly  follow  the  priorities  identified  in  the  Conceptual Wastewater 
Masterplan,16 capital investment and asset management program (footnote 8), and the Bagmati 
Action Plan, and will be implemented in coordination with the Bagmati River Basin Improvement 
Project (footnote 11). The project outputs will be as follows: 
 
(i)  Output  1:  Sewerage  network  rehabilitated  and  expanded.  This  output  will 
include  (a)  rehabilitation  and  expansion  of  the  sewerage  network,  including 
property connections; (b) construction of interceptor sewers along the river banks; 
and (c) rehabilitation of sewage pumping stations. 
(ii)  Output  2:  Wastewater  treatment  plants  modernized  and  expanded.  This 
output will include (a) modernization and expansion of five WWTPs to provide 90.5 
MLD capacity, (b) energy generation through sludge digestion and gasification, 
and (c) decentralized wastewater treatment systems in low-income areas. Details 
of  decentralized  wastewater  treatment  systems  are  available  in  the  project 
administration manual (PAM).17  
(iii)  Output  3:  Capacities strengthened  and  operational  and financial reforms 
institutionalized. This output will include continuation of the support provided 
through  ongoing  projects  for  (a)  capacity  building  of  KUKL,  KVWSMB,  and 
WSTFC; (b) development of a wastewater master plan, condition assessment of 
the existing sewerage network, update of the sewerage connection database, 
operationalization of a sewerage geographic information system (GIS), and an 
asset  management  plan;  (c)  community  participation  and  public  education  for 
health,  hygiene,  and  behavior  change  in  water  conservation  and  wastewater 
management practices, including the "3Rs" (reduce, reuse, and recycle); (d) a 
gender  equality  and  social  inclusion  action  plan;  and  (e)  support  for  project 
management. 
 
 
 
 
                                                
14  ADB. 2009. Country Partnership Strategy: Nepal, 2010–2012. Manila. 
15  ADB. 2012. Country Operations Business Plan: Nepal, 2013–2015. Manila. 
16  The Conceptual Wastewater Masterplan, 2010–2025 was prepared in 2010 and is in line with Bagmati Action Plan. 
17  Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

4 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
10.  The  project  is  estimated  to  cost  $137  million  (Table  1).  Detailed  cost  estimates  by 
expenditure category are in the PAM (footnote 17). 
 
Table 1: Project Investment Plan  
($ million) 
Item    Amount a 
A.  Base Cost    
  1.  Rehabilitation and expansion of sewerage network  58.83 
  2.  Modernization and expansion of wastewater treatment plants  40.08 
  3.  Capacity building and support for operational and financial improvements  7.17 
    Subtotal (A)  106.08 
B.  Taxes and Duties b  16.18 
C.  Contingencies c  12.17 
D.  Financing Charges During Implementation                2.57 
      Total (A+B+C+D)     137.00 
a  Exchange rate of $1 = NRs88 is used; Amount  is in mid-2012 prices.

and duties are the responsibility of the government. 
c  Physical contingencies are computed at 2.4% for civil works and equipment. Price contingencies are computed 
at 2.0% for foreign exchange costs and 6.5% for local currency costs. 
       Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
11.  The government has requested a loan in various currencies equivalent to $80 million from 
ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources  to finance  the  project. The  loan  will  have  a  32-year  term, 
including a grace period of 8 years, an interest charge of 1.0% per annum during the grace period 
and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms and conditions set forth in the loan and 
project agreements. The loan will finance 58.4% of the project cost, including part of the civil 
works  (output  1  and  output  2)  and  part  of the  operational  and financial  improvements and 
capacity  building  (output  3).  The  government  has  requested  cofinancing  of  $16.3  million, 
including $16.0 million as a loan and $0.3 million as a grant from the OFID to finance 11.9% of 
the project cost. The loan and grant, to be partially administered by ADB, will have a 20-year 
term, including a grace period of 5 years, and an interest charge of 2.25% per annum. The OFID 
loan and grant will be used to finance part of the civil works (output 1 and output 2). 
 
12.  The government will contribute $40.7 million, or 29.7% of the total project cost, to finance 
taxes and duties, resettlement costs, and part of the civil works and equipment, and will provide 
the loan proceeds and counterpart funds to the KVWSMB in a loan–grant mix of 20:80 at an 
interest rate of 3% per annum on the loan portion and a term of 30 years, including a grace period 
of 7 years. The KVWSMB will provide the loan proceeds and the government counterpart funds to 
KUKL based on the existing 30-year lease and an operating agreement between the KVWSMB 
and KUKL. These arrangements will be described in a subsidiary financing agreement acceptable 
to ADB, to be signed and be effective before KUKL can receive the loan proceeds and the 
counterpart funds. The government will assume the foreign exchange risk. The financing plan is 
in Table 2. 
 
Table 2: Financing Plan  
Source  Amount ($ million)  Share of Total (%)

for International Development

    Total  137.00  100.0 
     Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

5 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in 
the PAM (footnote 17). The Ministry of Urban Development will be the executing agency and 
KUKL, through its existing Project Implementation Directorate (PID), will be the implementing 
agency. Procurement of works, goods, and services financed by ADB and OFID will be carried 
out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Consultant selection and engagement will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The project will follow universal 
procurement.

supervision, and management consultant; HPCIDBC = High Powered Committee for Integrated Development of the

Management Board; MOEST = Ministry of Environment, Science and Technology; MOF = Ministry of Finance;

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
14.  Improvement of service delivery and regulation. The project will strengthen KUKL’s 
capacity  to  improve  its  wastewater  operations,  and  KVWSMB’s  and  WSTFC’s  respective 
capacities as asset owner and regulator. KUKL will develop a proper organizational structure and 
deploy  adequate  personnel  for  its  sewerage  operations  to  handle  additional  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) responsibilities.

6 
 
15.  Condition  assessment  survey,  geographic  information  system,  and  asset 
management  plan.  The  project  will  support  KVWSMB  and  KUKL  to  carry  out  a  condition 
assessment survey and develop a sewerage GIS and an asset management plan, focusing on an 
integrated approach to repairing, maintaining, rehabilitating, and replacing sewerage assets. 
 
16.  Adoption  of  energy  efficient  treatment  processes  and  energy  generation  from 
sludge. The existing WWTPs are located in densely populated areas and current processes are 
inefficient and ineffective.  Under the project, existing WWTPs will be upgraded  with energy 
efficient  and  mechanized  treatment  processes,  and  WWTP  designs  will  integrate  septage 
handling facilities. To mitigate the problem of intermittent and unreliable power supply, the project 
will facilitate (i) energy generation from sludge digestion or gasification, (ii) dedicated power 
supply from the national grid, and (iii) standby diesel generator sets. 
 
17.  Operation  and  maintenance  embedded  construction  contracts  for  operational 
sustainability. The project will include O&M embedded construction contracts combining design, 
construction, and O&M for WWTPs for a sufficiently long period (5–7 years). This will mitigate 
KUKL’s lack of O&M capacity, improve the quality of construction by providing continuity in 
system operation, and obligate KUKL to allocate adequate O&M budget.   
 
18.  Separation of sanitary sewers from storm water drains. The Kathmandu Valley has a 
combined  sewer  and  storm  water  drainage  system.  Various  reports  in  the  past  have 
recommended separating these systems. The project will promote separation of storm water and 
sanitary sewer systems in most of the areas, while recognizing that complete separation is 
difficult and impractical in some locations. 
 
19.  Integrated  planning  and  development  of  wastewater  treatment  plant  sites.  The 
project will support integrated planning and development of WWTP sites and surrounding areas, 
especially at Dhobighat, which will focus on (i) landscaping, plantation, and gardens; (ii) solid-
waste management; (iii) development of water bodies; and (iv) riverfront development including 
educational and recreational activities such as water sports, walkways, restaurants, etc.    
 
20.  Links with Melamchi tunnel project. The project assumes the availability of 170 MLD 
water from the Melamchi tunnel and assessment of current progress of the Melamchi tunnel 
indicates that it is likely to be completed by 2016 as per the updated plan. The government will 
monitor progress of the Melamchi tunnel to ensure timely completion. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
21.  Economic analysis. The estimated economic internal rate of return (EIRR) is 14.6%; the 
net present value is $24.6 million. The EIRR is higher than the economic opportunity cost of 
capital, estimated at 12.0%, indicating sufficient economic return. The results from sensitivity 
analysis, ranging from 13.4% to 14.5%, are satisfactory against downside risks, including 10% 
increase in capital expenditure, 10% increase in operating costs, 10% decrease in benefits, and 
1-year delay in project completion. The EIRR is most sensitive to a reduction in beneficiaries. 
High population growth is likely to sustain demand for water supply and sanitation services.18   
 
22.  Financial analysis. The estimated financial internal rate of return is 3.22%; the net 
present value is NRs4,197 million ($47.7 million). The financial internal rate of return is higher 
than the weighted average cost of capital, estimated at 1.11%, indicating reasonable financial 
return.  The  results  from  sensitivity  analysis,  ranging  from  2.34%  to  3.03%,  are  satisfactory 
                                                
18 Details are included in the economic analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

7 
against downside risks, including capital cost overruns by 10%, O&M cost overruns by 10%, and 
revenue reduced by 10%. The proposed water tariff and sewerage tariff sufficient to fully recover 
O&M costs are approximately 1.25% of income for low-income households, implying that the 
project is also affordable for low-income households.19   
 
23.  Financial sustainability. The capacity building and public–private partnership team will 
support KUKL focusing on (i) rationalization of tariffs; (ii) improvement of collection efficiency; (iii) 
recovery of arrears with adequate provisioning for bad debts; (iv) computerization of operations 
and financial management; (v) improvement of cash management and use of banks; (vi) field 
verifications of house connections; and (vii) introduction of sewerage tariffs for big consumers 
(hotels, etc.) proportionate to the volume of wastewater discharged.   
 
C.  Governance 
24.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and the PID. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM (footnote 17). Risk assessment was made with the help of a tool 
specifically  developed  for  Nepal.20  Based  on  these  assessments,  some  of  the  mitigation 
measures  incorporated  in  the  project  design  aim  to  (i)  establish  a  mechanism  for  regular 
voluntary disclosure of project-related information to citizens; (ii) develop and update a project 
website to enhance transparency in project implementation, procurement, and safeguards; and 
(iii) establish a grievance redress mechanism to ensure quick and effective resolution. 
 
25.  Coordination with the High Powered Committee for Integrated Development of the 
Bagmati  Civilization.  The  project  shares  the  vision  of  the  High  Powered  Committee  for 
Integrated Development of the Bagmati Civilization (HPCIDBC) to improve the water quality in the 
Bagmati River and its tributaries. Accordingly, under the project the WWTPs at Guheswori and 
Gokarna will be rehabilitated to higher effluent standards to improve water quality upstream of the 
holy Pasupatinath Temple. Moreover, the project will coordinate with the HPCIDBC to develop 
common design standards for sewerage systems. 
 
26.  Coordination with other agencies for proper solid-waste management. Currently, 
substantial  quantities  of  solid  waste  are  dumped  in  the  Bagmati  River  and  its  tributaries, 
aggravating  the  already  poor  quality  of  water  caused  by  disposal  of  untreated  sewage.  In 
addition, solid waste is frequently disposed of in sewers and manholes, causing blockages, 
flooding, and operational problems. The project will coordinate with municipalities and other 
agencies to improve solid-waste management through community awareness and participation. 
 
27.  Institutional  arrangements  of  Kathmandu  Upatyaka  Khanepani  Limited.  The 
government  will  refine  KUKL’s  institutional  structure  to  enforce  its  accountability  to  the 
government and citizens, and to ensure sustainability of its operations.       
  
D.  Poverty and Social 
28.  The project is classified as effective gender mainstreaming. A poverty and social analysis 
has been completed,21 and the project gives priority to connecting all poor  households and 
households headed by women to the sewerage network in the project area. The government and 
KUKL  will  reform  the  current  sewerage  connections  policy  to  facilitate  individual  sewerage 
                                                
19  Details are included in the financial analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
20  Peace Filter for Design and Implementation of Project (accessible from the list of supplementary documents in 
Appendix 2). 
21  Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

8 
connections to the poor, socially excluded, and households headed by women. Connection fees 
will be reduced for poor households under the project. A gender equality and social inclusion 
action  plan  was  prepared  with  clear  targets,  responsibilities,  and  resource  allocation.22  A 
community awareness and participation plan has also been prepared under the project to involve 
key stakeholders for widespread, ongoing, and meaningful participation.23 The PID will implement 
the gender equality and social inclusion and community awareness and participation plan, with 
support from the community awareness and participation consultant recruited under the project.  
 
29.  Pro-poor  and  gender-inclusive  sanitation  services.  Building  on  the  low-income 
consumer service unit strategy developed by KUKL, the project will complement KUKL's ongoing 
efforts to further strengthen its pro-poor and gender-inclusive sanitation services by focusing on 
(i) implementing appropriate measures to make the Kathmandu Valley open-defecation free; (ii) 
study  of  past  sanitation  projects  in  low-income  consumer  areas,  including  decentralized 
wastewater treatment systems, and drawing applicable lessons from such sanitation projects; (iii) 
incorporating strategies for pro-poor and gender-sensitive sanitation services in KUKL's future 
investment plans and wastewater master plans; (iv) recording data on underserved settlements in 
the GIS; and (v) piloting alternative onsite sanitation in selected low-income areas. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
30.  Social safeguards. The project is classified category B for involuntary resettlement and 
category C for indigenous peoples. A resettlement plan24 and a resettlement framework25 were 
prepared  and  disclosed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  and 
Operation Manual.26 The project does not include any component that will require land acquisition 
or resettlement activities causing any significant impact. All sites for the construction of WWTPs 
and sewerage network are located within existing WWTP sites or on government land along 
roads or riverbanks. The decentralized wastewater treatment systems shall be located in places 
that do not require any land acquisition. Most of the land acquisition for the WWTPs was carried 
out during the late 1970s and early 1980s. The project will ensure that the land acquired for 
WWTPs continues to comply with all relevant laws and policies of the government. The impacts 
during construction will be limited to (i) temporary losses for a few cultivators along the riverbanks 
during the laying of sewers, (ii) temporary disruption of business activities and shifting of vendors 
and hawkers during construction works, and (iii) permanent loss of access to land for a few 
informal  cultivators  at  the  Gokarna  WWTP  site.  The  compensation  for  lost  income  will  be 
provided to those affected as per the resettlement plan and resettlement framework. No adverse 
impacts on indigenous peoples are anticipated, and improved wastewater facilities will benefit all 
households including indigenous peoples in the project areas. The project will avoid cultural sites 
used by indigenous peoples, if identified during detailed design. Meaningful and widespread 
consultations will continue with all communities in the project area. The government will initiate 
acquisition of land at Khokana for future construction of the WWTP. The project will support the 
study of technical and environmental feasibility and adequate protection of this site.   
 
31.  Environmental safeguards. The project is classified category B for environment. An 
initial environmental examination (IEE)27 and environmental management plan were prepared 
and disclosed in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). An environmental 
                                                
22  Gender Equality and Social Inclusion Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
23  Community Awareness and Participation Plan (accessible from the list of supplementary documents in Appendix 2). 
24  Resettlement Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
25  Resettlement Framework (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
26  ADB. 20120. Safeguard Policy Statement. Operations Manual. OM F1/BP. Manila. 
27  Initial Environmental Examination (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
assessment and review framework28 was prepared to guide the environmental assessment of 
pilot decentralized wastewater treatment systems. The IEE and the environmental management 
plan will be updated during detailed design and incorporated into contract documents. The IEE 
shows  substantive  net  positive  environmental  benefit,  including  (i)  improved  wastewater 
management to safeguard public health, and (ii) cleaner waterways and urban environment 
through increased sewage treatment. Additional measures will be taken during pipe laying works 
within roads passing through heritage areas to ensure there are no impacts during construction. 
Permission from the Department of Archaeology will be obtained prior to commencement of 
construction,  particularly  in  Patan  and  Darbar  Squares.  Measures  to  manage  any  impacts 
pertaining  to  slope  stability,  erosion,  and  sedimentation  will  be  implemented  prior  to  laying 
interceptors along the rivers. As part of the detailed design of the new WWTPs, air quality 
dispersion modeling will be conducted to ensure odor management measures are incorporated 
into the environmental monitoring system. In addition, perimeter buffers will be established along 
the boundaries of the WWTPs to minimize odors released from the premises. To ensure optimal 
operations of WWTPs at all times, safety plans will be developed and implemented.29 
 
32.  Environmental  monitoring  of  wastewater  quality.  The  project  will  support  the 
government to monitor environmental regulatory standards. This will include development of (i) 
domestic sewage discharge standards,30 (ii) a mechanism for monitoring the quality of discharge 
to  streams  and  rivers  in  the  valley,  (iii)  a  properly  equipped  laboratory,  (iv)  procedures for 
enforcement of pretreatment of industrial effluent before discharging to sewer network or stream, 
(v) a septage management plan, and (vi) processing and disposal of sludge and screenings.  
 
33.  Natural disasters and climate change adaptation and mitigation. The project will 
incorporate  adequate  adaptation  measures  for  the  risks  related  to  earthquakes,  landslides, 
floods, and climate change. The detailed designs of the project components will consider the 
findings from ongoing strategic programs for climate resilience as basis for incorporating possible 
climate change adaptation measures. These programs were funded by ADB and development 
partners through the Pilot Program for Climate Resilience of the Climate Investment Funds.31 The 
project will facilitate energy generation through the use of sludge produced and collected at 
WWTPs, which will help mitigate climate change impacts.   
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
34.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail in 
the risk assessment and risk management plan.32 The integrated benefits and impacts of the 
project are expected to outweigh the costs. 
 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Transition to a federal  Development partners will maintain close dialogue with the government and other 
structure, the peace process,  stakeholders to ensure that the development and reform process is not derailed. 
and political instability may  The project will involve key stakeholders generating consensus for its successful 
affect project implementation.  implementation. 
Water from the Melamchi  MOUD and ADB will closely monitor the tunnel work to ensure timely completion. 
tunnel may not be available on  Regular ADB missions will be fielded to update the risk assessment and suggest 
time.  further mitigation measures. 
                                                
28  Environmental Assessment and Review Framework (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
29  WWTP safety plans use a comprehensive risk management approach for all steps in the process. 
30  Standards for industrial and commercial discharge are available in the Environmental Protection Act. 
31  ADB. 2011. Technical Assistance to Nepal for Mainstreaming Climate Change Risk Management in Development. 
Manila (TA 7984-NEP, $7,163,000, approved on 14 December 2011). This technical assistance will facilitate 
preparation of climate risk management manuals, guidelines, and standards for key infrastructure sectors. 
32   Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Delays in project  MOUD and KUKL will assign qualified staff to the PID and minimize staff turnover. 
implementation, including  The design, supervision, and management consultant will support project 
availability of clear sites, may  management, safeguards, reporting, and training on FIDIC contracts. Large 
result in cost and time  contract packages will be designed to attract international bidders. MOUD will 
overruns.  ensure possession and security of land acquired for project works.  
Lack of coordination among  The project steering committee will provide direction and guidance for 
various agencies may result in  coordination. The roles, responsibilities, and functions of the PID, KUKL, and 
suboptimal outcome.  HPCIDBC will be clearly delineated. The interagency coordination committee will 
ensure effective coordination. 
KUKL may not implement the  MOUD and KUKL will review and establish a proper institutional structure for 
proposed institutional  KUKL to ensure its accountability to the government and citizens. MOUD will 
arrangements, staffing, and  ensure competent staff in KUKL. The capacity building and public–private 
measures for financial  partnership team will support KUKL to improve its operating and financial 
sustainability.  systems. Implementation of the business plan will be closely monitored. 
Lack of availability of power for  KUKL will ensure dedicated 24-hour power supply line for the WWTPs from the 
the wastewater treatment  national electricity grid. In addition, energy generation from sludge and back-up 
plants  diesel generators will be installed in the WWTPs. 
ADB  =  Asian  Development  Bank,  FIDIC  =  Fédération  Internationale  Des  Ingénieurs-Conseils  (International 
Federation of Consulting Engineers), HPCIDBC = High Powered Committee for Integrated Development of the 
Bagmati Civilization, KUKL = Kathmandu Upatyaka Khanepani, MOUD = Ministry of Urban Development, PID = 
Project Implementation Directorate, WWTP = wastewater treatment plant. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
35.  The government and KUKL have assured ADB that implementation of the project will 
conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies,  including those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement and standard legal 
conditions,  as  described  in  the  project  administration  manual  and  loan  documents.  The 
government and KUKL have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set 
forth in the loan and project agreements.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
36.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the President, under the provisions 
of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the Board approve  
(i)  the  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to  $80,000,000  to  Nepal  for  the 
Kathmandu Valley Wastewater Management Project from ADB’s Special Funds 
resources with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace 
period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a grace 
period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented 
to the Board; and 
(ii)  the administration by ADB of the loan not exceeding the equivalent of $16,000,000  
and  the  grant  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $300,000  to  Nepal  for  the 
Kathmandu  Valley  Wastewater  Management  Project,  to  be  provided  by  the 
Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries Fund for International Development 
(OFID).  
 
Bindu N. Lohani 
Ranking Vice-President 
02 April 2013
